result.markdown:
--- title: "Ibis 9.0: SQLGlot-ification" author: "Ibis team" date: "2024-04-18" categories: - release - blog --- ## Overview Ibis 9.0 completes ["the big refactor"](../../posts/roadmap-2024-H1/index.qmd#the-big-refactor), completing the transition from SQLAlchemy to [SQLGlot](https://github.com/tobymao/sqlglot) and drastically simplifying the codebase. This is a big step toward stabilized internals and allows us to more easily add new features and backends going forward. Ibis 9.0 also adds new functionality, fixes many bugs, and welcomes a new committer to the project! ### New committer We're excited to welcome [Nick Crews](https://github.com/NickCrews) as the newest committer to the Ibis project! Nick has been a long-time contributor to Ibis, one of the most active people on the issue tracker, and increasingly involved in the community. We're excited to have him on board! ## Backends No new backends were added in this release, [unless you count the April Fools' Day Unix backend](../unix-backend/index.qmd)! As always, there have been backend-specific improvements and bug fixes. Some highlights are below. Check the [full changelog](../../release_notes.qmd) for more details. ### Snowflake You can now run Ibis inside of a Snowflake stored procedure! Look for a blog on this coming soon. ### DuckDB With [DuckDB's addition of MySQL as a database it can attach to](https://duckdb.org/2024/01/26/multi-database-support-in-duckdb.html), we've added a `read_mysql` function to Ibis inline with `read_postgres` and `read_sqlite`. ### PySpark PySpark 3.5 is now supported. ### Apache Flink Scalar user-defined functions (UDFs) are now supported in the Flink backend. ### RisingWave Streaming data definition language (DDL) support has been added to the RisingWave backend. ## Breaking changes You can view the [full changelog](../../release_notes.qmd) for additional breaking changes. There is [one we expect to affect many users](#what-does-schema-mean). If you're new to Ibis, see [how to install](../../../install.qmd) and [the getting started tutorial](../../../tutorials/getting_started.qmd). To follow along with this blog, ensure you're on `'ibis-framework>=9,<10'`. First, we’ll setup Ibis for interactive use: ::: {#20536e23 .cell execution_count=2} ``` {.python .cell-code} import ibis import ibis.selectors as s ibis.options.interactive = True ibis.options.repr.interactive.max_rows = 3 ``` ::: And fetch the penguins dataset: ::: {#0619a04d .cell execution_count=3} ``` {.python .cell-code} t = ibis.examples.penguins.fetch() t ``` ::: {.cell-output .cell-output-display execution_count=2} ```{=html} 
┏━━━━━━━━━┳━━━━━━━━━━━┳━━━━━━━━━━━━━━━━┳━━━━━━━━━━━━━━━┳━━━━━━━━━━━━━━━━━━━┳━━━━━━━━━━━━━┳━━━━━━━━┳━━━━━━━┓
┃ species ┃ island    ┃ bill_length_mm ┃ bill_depth_mm ┃ flipper_length_mm ┃ body_mass_g ┃ sex    ┃ year  ┃
┡━━━━━━━━━╇━━━━━━━━━━━╇━━━━━━━━━━━━━━━━╇━━━━━━━━━━━━━━━╇━━━━━━━━━━━━━━━━━━━╇━━━━━━━━━━━━━╇━━━━━━━━╇━━━━━━━┩
│ string  │ string    │ float64        │ float64       │ int64             │ int64       │ string │ int64 │
├─────────┼───────────┼────────────────┼───────────────┼───────────────────┼─────────────┼────────┼───────┤
│ Adelie  │ Torgersen │           39.1 │          18.7 │               181 │        3750 │ male   │  2007 │
│ Adelie  │ Torgersen │           39.5 │          17.4 │               186 │        3800 │ female │  2007 │
│ Adelie  │ Torgersen │           40.3 │          18.0 │               195 │        3250 │ female │  2007 │
│ …       │ …         │              … │             … │                 … │           … │ …      │     … │
└─────────┴───────────┴────────────────┴───────────────┴───────────────────┴─────────────┴────────┴───────┘
``` ::: ::: ### What does "schema" mean? In Ibis, a "schema" is a mapping of column names to their types: ::: {#a8828220 .cell execution_count=4} ``` {.python .cell-code} t.schema() ``` ::: {.cell-output .cell-output-display execution_count=3} ``` ibis.Schema { species string island string bill_length_mm float64 bill_depth_mm float64 flipper_length_mm int64 body_mass_g int64 sex string year int64 } ``` ::: ::: And as of Ibis 9.0, that is all "schema" means! In building a standard Python dataframe interface, we must standardize naming conventions and terminology across data systems. Many systems use the words "schema", "database", "catalog", and "namespace" to mean different things. We have standardizes on `table` as the container of data which has a `schema`. A `database` is a collection of tables, and a `catalog` is a collection of databases. Not all backends will support all levels of hierarchy. Using other `schema` methods as of Ibis 9.0 will give a deprecation warning, and the arguments throughout the API have been updated to reflect the standardization. For example, `list_schemas()` will give a deprecation warning: ::: {#8973cef5 .cell execution_count=5} ``` {.python .cell-code} con = ibis.connect("duckdb://") con.list_schemas() ``` ::: {.cell-output .cell-output-stderr} ``` /var/folders/hm/f6m13d5d4xg6v606d3mfndnh0000gn/T/ipykernel_20689/2769547408.py:2: FutureWarning: `CanListSchema.list_schemas` is deprecated as of v9.0, removed in v10.0; Use `list_databases` instead` ``` ::: ::: {.cell-output .cell-output-display execution_count=4} ``` ['information_schema', 'main', 'pg_catalog'] ``` ::: ::: Use `list_databases()` instead: ::: {#04d04f20 .cell execution_count=6} ``` {.python .cell-code} con.list_databases() ``` ::: {.cell-output .cell-output-display execution_count=5} ``` ['information_schema', 'main', 'pg_catalog'] ``` ::: ::: You can also `list_catalogs()`: ::: {#83e1adf7 .cell execution_count=7} ``` {.python .cell-code} con.list_catalogs() ``` ::: {.cell-output .cell-output-display execution_count=6} ``` ['memory', 'system', 'temp'] ``` ::: ::: And get the current database: ::: {#8c9a8d97 .cell execution_count=8} ``` {.python .cell-code} con.current_database ``` ::: {.cell-output .cell-output-display execution_count=7} ``` 'main' ``` ::: ::: And the current catalog: ::: {#05fda4cf .cell execution_count=9} ``` {.python .cell-code} con.current_catalog ``` ::: {.cell-output .cell-output-display execution_count=8} ``` 'memory' ``` ::: ::: ### Other breaking changes There were a few more minor breaking changes, see [the full changelog](../../release_notes.qmd) for more details. ## Functionality A lot of new functionality has been added in Ibis 9.0. ### Python 3.12 [Ibis now supports Python 3.12](https://github.com/ibis-project/ibis/pull/8529)! ### Describe Ibis now has a `describe` method to get a summary of a table: ::: {#e1663410 .cell execution_count=11} ``` {.python .cell-code} t.describe() ``` ::: {.cell-output .cell-output-display execution_count=10} ```{=html} 
┏━━━━━━━━━━━━━━━━━━━┳━━━━━━━━━┳━━━━━━━┳━━━━━━━┳━━━━━━━━┳━━━━━━━━┳━━━━━━━━━━━━━┳━━━━━━━━━━━━┳━━━━━━━━━┳━━━━━━━━━━┳━━━━━━━━━┳━━━━━━━━━┳━━━━━━━━━┓
┃ name              ┃ type    ┃ count ┃ nulls ┃ unique ┃ mode   ┃ mean        ┃ std        ┃ min     ┃ p25      ┃ p50     ┃ p75     ┃ max     ┃

│ string            │ string  │ int64 │ int64 │ int64  │ string │ float64     │ float64    │ float64 │ float64  │ float64 │ float64 │ float64 │

│ island            │ string  │   344 │     0 │      3 │ Biscoe │        NULL │       NULL │    NULL │     NULL │    NULL │    NULL │    NULL │

│ bill_depth_mm     │ float64 │   344 │     2 │     80 │ NULL   │   17.151170 │   1.974793 │    13.1 │   15.600 │   17.30 │    18.7 │    21.5 │

│ body_mass_g       │ int64   │   344 │     2 │     94 │ NULL   │ 4201.754386 │ 801.954536 │  2700.0 │ 3550.000 │ 4050.00 │  4750.0 │  6300.0 │

└───────────────────┴─────────┴───────┴───────┴────────┴────────┴─────────────┴────────────┴─────────┴──────────┴─────────┴─────────┴─────────┘
``` ::: ::: ### GraphViz custom attributes Thanks to [a couple](https://github.com/ibis-project/ibis/pull/8510) [community contributions](https://github.com/ibis-project/ibis/pull/8527), you can now pass custom attributes to the GraphViz visualization of an expression. :::{.callout-tip} You can also call `expr.visualize()` and pass the same arguments. ::: ::: {#60677005 .cell execution_count=13} ``` {.python .cell-code} from ibis.expr.visualize import to_graph expr = ( t.group_by("species", "island") .agg(count=t.count()) .order_by(ibis._["count"].desc()) ) to_graph( expr, label_edges=True, node_attr={"shape": "hexagon", "color": "green", "fontname": "Roboto Mono"}, edge_attr={"fontsize": "12", "fontname": "Comic Sans MS"}, ) ``` ::: {.cell-output .cell-output-display execution_count=12} ![](index_files/figure-html/cell-13-output-1.svg){} ::: ::: ### Polars input and output You can now directly output a Polars dataframe from an Ibis table (instead of going through Apache Arrow as previously possible): ::: {#39be1327 .cell execution_count=14} ``` {.python .cell-code} t.to_polars() ``` ::: {.cell-output .cell-output-display execution_count=13} ```{=html}
shape: (344, 8)
speciesislandbill_length_mmbill_depth_mmflipper_length_mmbody_mass_gsexyear
strstrf64f64i64i64stri64

"Adelie""Torgersen"39.517.41863800"female"2007
"Adelie""Torgersen"40.318.01953250"female"2007
"Adelie""Torgersen"nullnullnullnullnull2007
"Adelie""Torgersen"36.719.31933450"female"2007
……………………
"Chinstrap""Dream"55.819.82074000"male"2009
"Chinstrap""Dream"43.518.12023400"female"2009
"Chinstrap""Dream"49.618.21933775"male"2009
"Chinstrap""Dream"50.819.02104100"male"2009
"Chinstrap""Dream"50.218.71983775"female"2009
``` ::: ::: And you can directly input a Polars dataframe into an Ibis memtable: ::: {#85c753ee .cell execution_count=15} ``` {.python .cell-code} ibis.memtable(t.to_polars()) ``` ::: {.cell-output .cell-output-display execution_count=14} ```{=html} 
┏━━━━━━━━━┳━━━━━━━━━━━┳━━━━━━━━━━━━━━━━┳━━━━━━━━━━━━━━━┳━━━━━━━━━━━━━━━━━━━┳━━━━━━━━━━━━━┳━━━━━━━━┳━━━━━━━┓

``` ::: ::: These conversions are efficient and improve usability of Ibis and Polars together. ### Scalar subqueries from expressions You can now create scalar subqueries from expressions: ::: {#b1847670 .cell execution_count=16} ``` {.python .cell-code} t.select("species").limit(1).as_scalar() ``` ::: {.cell-output .cell-output-display} ```{=html} 

```
:::

::: {.ansi-escaped-output}
```{=html}

'Adelie'

```
:::

:::
:::


### Disconnect

You can now explicitly disconnect from a backend. First, connect to a backend:

::: {#332ada0a .cell execution_count=17}
``` {.python .cell-code}
con = ibis.connect("duckdb://")
con.list_tables()
```

::: {.cell-output .cell-output-display execution_count=16}
```
[]
```
:::
:::


Then you can disconnect. Trying to use the connection after will raise an error:

::: {#89400ef1 .cell execution_count=18}
``` {.python .cell-code}
con.disconnect()
con.list_tables()
```

::: {.cell-output .cell-output-error}
```
ConnectionException: Connection Error: Connection has already been closed
```
:::
:::


### Today

You can now get the current date more easily:

::: {#8a5d67b3 .cell execution_count=19}
``` {.python .cell-code}
ibis.today()
```

::: {.cell-output .cell-output-display}
```{=html}


```
:::

::: {.cell-output .cell-output-display execution_count=18}

::: {.ansi-escaped-output}
```{=html}

datetime.date(2024, 4, 16)

```
:::

:::
:::


And use it in expressions:

::: {#62257760 .cell execution_count=20}
``` {.python .cell-code}
t.mutate(ingested_at=ibis.today()).relocate("ingested_at")
```

::: {.cell-output .cell-output-display execution_count=19}
```{=html}

┏━━━━━━━━━━━━━┳━━━━━━━━━┳━━━━━━━━━━━┳━━━━━━━━━━━━━━━━┳━━━━━━━━━━━━━━━┳━━━━━━━━━━━━━━━━━━━┳━━━━━━━━━━━━━┳━━━━━━━━┳━━━━━━━┓
┃ ingested_at ┃ species ┃ island    ┃ bill_length_mm ┃ bill_depth_mm ┃ flipper_length_mm ┃ body_mass_g ┃ sex    ┃ year  ┃

### UUIDs

You can now generate universally unique identifiers (UUIDs) in Ibis more easily:

::: {#93d657aa .cell execution_count=21}
``` {.python .cell-code}
ibis.uuid()
```

::: {.cell-output .cell-output-display}
```{=html}


```
:::

::: {.cell-output .cell-output-display execution_count=20}

::: {.ansi-escaped-output}
```{=html}

UUID('f4687091-5dc2-40d8-b900-bd89c79ee412')

```
:::

:::
:::


And use them in expressions:

::: {#da7d2f7f .cell execution_count=22}
``` {.python .cell-code}
t.mutate(id=ibis.uuid()).relocate("id")
```

::: {.cell-output .cell-output-display execution_count=21}
```{=html}

┏━━━━━━━━━━━━━━━━━━━━━━━━━━━━━━━━━━━━━━┳━━━━━━━━━┳━━━━━━━━━━━┳━━━━━━━━━━━━━━━━┳━━━━━━━━━━━━━━━┳━━━━━━━━━━━━━━━━━━━┳━━━━━━━━━━━━━┳━━━━━━━━┳━━━━━━━┓
┃ id                                   ┃ species ┃ island    ┃ bill_length_mm ┃ bill_depth_mm ┃ flipper_length_mm ┃ body_mass_g ┃ sex    ┃ year  ┃
┡━━━━━━━━━━━━━━━━━━━━━━━━━━━━━━━━━━━━━━╇━━━━━━━━━╇━━━━━━━━━━━╇━━━━━━━━━━━━━━━━╇━━━━━━━━━━━━━━━╇━━━━━━━━━━━━━━━━━━━╇━━━━━━━━━━━━━╇━━━━━━━━╇━━━━━━━┩

### TopK includes NULLs

This could technically be considered a breaking change or bug fix. Regardless,
`topk` now includes NULLs by default:

::: {#d363bf42 .cell execution_count=23}
``` {.python .cell-code}
t["sex"].topk(3)
```

::: {.cell-output .cell-output-display execution_count=22}
```{=html}

┏━━━━━━━━┳━━━━━━━━━━━━━━━━━━━━━┓
┃ sex    ┃ CountStar(penguins) ┃
┡━━━━━━━━╇━━━━━━━━━━━━━━━━━━━━━┩
│ string │ int64               │
├────────┼─────────────────────┤
│ male   │                 168 │
│ female │                 165 │
│ NULL   │                  11 │
└────────┴─────────────────────┘


```
:::
:::


### Order and group by variadic arguments

For consistency with other methods, `order_by` and `group_by` now accept
variadic arguments:

::: {#93c459be .cell execution_count=24}
``` {.python .cell-code}
t.order_by(t["body_mass_g"].desc(), "island", t["species"])
```

::: {.cell-output .cell-output-display execution_count=23}
```{=html}

┏━━━━━━━━━┳━━━━━━━━┳━━━━━━━━━━━━━━━━┳━━━━━━━━━━━━━━━┳━━━━━━━━━━━━━━━━━━━┳━━━━━━━━━━━━━┳━━━━━━━━┳━━━━━━━┓
┃ species ┃ island ┃ bill_length_mm ┃ bill_depth_mm ┃ flipper_length_mm ┃ body_mass_g ┃ sex    ┃ year  ┃
┡━━━━━━━━━╇━━━━━━━━╇━━━━━━━━━━━━━━━━╇━━━━━━━━━━━━━━━╇━━━━━━━━━━━━━━━━━━━╇━━━━━━━━━━━━━╇━━━━━━━━╇━━━━━━━┩
│ string  │ string │ float64        │ float64       │ int64             │ int64       │ string │ int64 │
├─────────┼────────┼────────────────┼───────────────┼───────────────────┼─────────────┼────────┼───────┤
│ Gentoo  │ Biscoe │           49.2 │          15.2 │               221 │        6300 │ male   │  2007 │
│ Gentoo  │ Biscoe │           59.6 │          17.0 │               230 │        6050 │ male   │  2007 │
│ Gentoo  │ Biscoe │           51.1 │          16.3 │               220 │        6000 │ male   │  2008 │
│ …       │ …      │              … │             … │                 … │           … │ …      │     … │
└─────────┴────────┴────────────────┴───────────────┴───────────────────┴─────────────┴────────┴───────┘


```
:::
:::


::: {#46a026df .cell execution_count=25}
``` {.python .cell-code}
grouped = (
    t.group_by("species", "island")
    .agg(count=t.count())
    .order_by(ibis._["count"].desc())
)
grouped
```

::: {.cell-output .cell-output-display execution_count=24}
```{=html}

┏━━━━━━━━━━━┳━━━━━━━━┳━━━━━━━┓
┃ species   ┃ island ┃ count ┃
┡━━━━━━━━━━━╇━━━━━━━━╇━━━━━━━┩
│ string    │ string │ int64 │
├───────────┼────────┼───────┤
│ Gentoo    │ Biscoe │   124 │
│ Chinstrap │ Dream  │    68 │
│ Adelie    │ Dream  │    56 │
│ …         │ …      │     … │
└───────────┴────────┴───────┘


```
:::
:::


You can still pass in a list or tuple if you prefer.

### Create more backends with empty URLs

For convenience, you can now create backends with an empty URL for Dask, pandas,
Polars, and DataFusion:

::: {#48deb0bb .cell execution_count=26}
``` {.python .cell-code}
con = ibis.connect("dask://")
con = ibis.connect("pandas://")
con = ibis.connect("polars://")
con = ibis.connect("datafusion://")
```
:::


This is in addition to the existing backend-specific connection methods:

::: {#bc687fc3 .cell execution_count=27}
``` {.python .cell-code}
con = ibis.dask.connect()
con = ibis.pandas.connect()
con = ibis.polars.connect()
con = ibis.datafusion.connect()
```
:::


Note that URL parameters are not meaningful with these backends. The main use
case is more convenient connection swapping programmatically:

::: {#818d79c0 .cell execution_count=28}
``` {.python .cell-code}
for backend in [
    "duckdb",
    "sqlite",
    "pyspark",
    "dask",
    "pandas",
    "polars",
    "datafusion",
]:
    con = ibis.connect(f"{backend}://")
    print(con)
```

::: {.cell-output .cell-output-stdout}
```







```
:::
:::


## Wrapping up

Ibis 9.0 is an exciting release that completes the transition to SQLGlot, adds a
lot of new functionality, and welcomes a new committer to the project!

As always, try Ibis by [installing](../../install.qmd) and [getting
started](../../tutorials/getting_started.qmd).

If you run into any issues or find support is lacking for your backend, [open an
issue](https://github.com/ibis-project/issues/new/choose) or
[discussion](https://github.com/ibis-project/discussions/new/choose) and let us
know!
